qas.question: What is a common myth about poultry and bacteria?

context: <b4_0>A 2011 study by the <a0_0>Translational Genomics Research<a0_0/> Institute<b4_0/> showed that <a1_0><b5_0>47%<b5_0/><a1_0/> of the meat and poultry sold in United States grocery stores was contaminated with Staphylococcus aureus, and 52% of the bacteria concerned showed resistance to at least three groups of antibiotics. <a2_0><b7_0>Thorough cooking of the product would kill these bacteria<b7_0/>,<a2_0/> but <a3_0>a risk of cross-contamination from improper handling of the raw product is still present<a3_0/>. Also, some risk is present for consumers of poultry meat and eggs to bacterial infections such as <b6_0>Salmonella and Campylobacter<b6_0/>. Poultry products may become contaminated by these bacteria during handling, processing, marketing, or storage, resulting in food-borne illness if the product is improperly cooked or handled.
